description: Acquisition, access, use, or disclosure of unsecured ePHI in a manner not permitted by law or authorization; presumed compromised unless entity demonstrates otherwise
regulatory_definition: Under HITECH Section 13400: acquisition, access, use, or disclosure of unsecured ePHI that compromises the security or privacy of the information; unsecured ePHI is presumed to be compromised unless entity conducts risk assessment demonstrating low probability of compromise
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Genetic Information; Biometric Data; Financial PHI; Substance Abuse Records; Mental Health Records; De-identified Data if re-identified; Pseudonymized Data if key compromised
typical_causes: Malware infection; Ransomware attack; Theft of device/records; Hacking/unauthorized access; Phishing attacks; Insider threat/employee misconduct; Lost or stolen portable device; Unencrypted backup; Insecure disposal; Vulnerable system; Weak password; Social engineering; Supply chain compromise; Natural disaster; Configuration error
detection_methods: Unauthorized user account activity; Unusual network traffic; Malware detection; Alert from security tools; Missing records or devices; Employee report; Law enforcement report; Customer complaint; Anomalous access patterns; Failed integrity checks; Ransomware note; Extortion demand; Dark web monitoring; Vulnerability scanning; Forensic investigation; Audit log analysis
investigation_scope: Full forensic investigation: determine scope of breach; identify affected individuals; identify breached data elements; trace attack vector; preserve evidence; determine compromise timeframe; assess attacker motivation; determine if data was actually exfiltrated; determine if data was used fraudulently; coordinate with law enforcement if criminal
notification_required: Yes - MANDATORY within 60 days unless risk assessment demonstrates no compromise
notification_timeline: 60 days from discovery of breach (HITECH Section 13402)
notification_recipients: Affected individuals (mail or email); Media if 500+ individuals affected in state (written notice); U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (OCR); State Attorney General if 500+ affected; Federal agencies if federal data affected; Law enforcement if criminal
risk_assessment_criteria: 4-factor risk assessment: (1) Nature and extent of unsecured ePHI; (2) Who acquired or accessed ePHI; (3) Whether ePHI was actually accessed or used; (4) Extent mitigation measures reduce risk; Factors favoring no breach: encryption remained intact; access logs show no unauthorized access; device recovered before access; data deleted before access; circumstantial evidence of non-use; known reason for access; legal/authorized access
remediation_requirements: Immediately contain breach: isolate affected system; reset passwords; revoke access; notify law enforcement; preserve evidence; implement corrective actions: patch vulnerability; implement encryption; enhance monitoring; improve access controls; retrain staff; review and update incident response plan; notify insurance; coordinate with legal counsel; prepare for regulatory investigation; establish breach response team; implement temporary enhanced monitoring; business continuity restoration; long-term safeguards enhancement
documentation_requirements: Document breach investigation: notice to individuals; notification to media; notification to HHS OCR; documentation of risk assessment findings; timeline of discovery; remediation actions; evidence preservation; forensic findings; cost of breach; insurance claims; regulatory correspondence; OCR responses; litigation documents; corrective action plan; compliance certifications; third-party assessments
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (primary); State Attorneys General; Department of Justice (if criminal); FBI (if criminal); State health departments; State insurance regulators; Plaintiffs attorneys; Media; Patients; Credit bureaus (for financial breaches)
penalty_tier: Tier 4 ($20K-$50K minimum per violation; up to $1.5M for category per year)
related_requirements: HITECH-13402-R1-R5 (Breach notification); HITECH-13404-R1-R2 (BA notification); HITECH-13406-R1-R4 (Civil penalties); HITECH-13409-R1-R2 (Criminal penalties); HITECH-13416-R1-R2 (Corrective action); HITECH-13418-R1 (Safe Harbor); Requirement for forensic investigation; Requirement for risk assessment; Requirement for notification
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Breach; Unauthorized Access; Data Compromise; Incident Response; Forensic Investigation; Risk Assessment; Breach Notification; OCR Enforcement; Civil Litigation; Criminal Investigation; Regulatory Compliance; Reputational Harm; Customer Notification; Crisis Management
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions - unsecured ePHI); Section 13402 (Breach notification requirement); Section 13404 (BA notification); Section 13406 (Civil penalties); Section 13409 (Criminal penalties); Section 13416 (Corrective action plans); Section 13418 (Safe Harbor); 45 CFR 164.400-414 (Breach Notification Rule)
success_criteria: Breach discovered within 24 hours; Investigation completed within 7 days; 4-factor risk assessment completed; Notification sent to individuals within 60 days; Notification to media completed; Notification to HHS OCR completed; Notification to State AGs completed; Forensic report completed; Corrective action plan developed; OCR communication initiated; All affected individuals notified; Media notification completed; Documentation organized; Legal hold implemented
failure_consequences: Failure results in: Tier 4 penalties ($20K-$50K+ per violation); Class action lawsuits; State AG enforcement; OCR investigation and audit; corrective action plan with monitoring; Safe Harbor protection lost; Criminal prosecution possible; Breach exposure for identity theft; Credit monitoring costs; Public notification costs; Reputational damage; Loss of patient trust; Media coverage; Regulatory scrutiny; Potential business closure; Executive liability; Insurance denial; Inability to resolve within regulatory timeframe

description: Disclosure of PHI to an entity not authorized to receive it under HIPAA Privacy Rule minimum necessary principle or specific HITECH restrictions; includes disclosure to unauthorized individuals employees contractors or external parties
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA and HITECH: disclosure of PHI in violation of Privacy Rule restrictions; disclosure without individual authorization except for permitted purposes; disclosure exceeding minimum necessary for the stated purpose; disclosure violating specific HITECH restrictions such as substance abuse records or genetic information protections
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Genetic Information; Biometric Data; Financial PHI; Substance Abuse Records; Mental Health Records; Deidentified Data if still identifiable; Pseudonymized Data if key disclosed
typical_causes: Unsecured email to wrong recipient; Posting PHI on public-facing website; Verbal disclosure to unauthorized individual; Social engineering leading to disclosure; Insider disclosure to family/friends; Document sent to wrong address; Fax to wrong number; Email misconfiguration; Unencrypted transmission; Improper disposal; Hard copy left in public area; Lack of access controls; Insufficient training; Inadequate audit controls; Temporary worker access; Contractor access not controlled
detection_methods: Unauthorized receipt of PHI confirmed; Patient complaint about unauthorized disclosure; Audit detecting unauthorized access; Business associate notification of disclosure; Regulatory inspection finding; Patient credit monitoring enrollment; Identity theft discovered; Law enforcement report; Media report; Social media disclosure; Dark web discovery
investigation_scope: Investigation: identify unauthorized recipient; determine what information was disclosed; assess risk of further disclosure; assess risk of misuse; determine how disclosure occurred; review access logs; interview staff; review email/communication logs; assess controls failures; determine if criminal activity involved; assess potential for identity theft; determine scope (single individual or widespread)
notification_required: Yes - if unauthorized recipient could cause harm; Risk assessment to determine notification necessity
notification_timeline: 60 days from discovery (if notification required); Notification only if risk assessment requires
notification_recipients: Affected individuals (if risk assessment requires); Media (if 500+ affected or high-risk disclosure); HHS OCR (if serious or pattern); State Attorney General (state law violations); Law enforcement (if criminal); Data subject (individual); Business Associate (if BA caused disclosure)
risk_assessment_criteria: Risk assessment: (1) What information disclosed; (2) Who received information; (3) Risk individual would use improperly; (4) Whether information was actually misused; Aggravating factors: substance abuse records (mandatory notification); genetic information (mandatory notification); mental health psychotherapy notes (mandatory notification); financial data with account numbers (high risk); SSN disclosed (high risk); Multiple individuals affected (high risk); Recipient unknown/outside organization (high risk); Recipient has criminal history (high risk)
remediation_requirements: Immediately contain: revoke access; restrict further disclosure; investigate extent of disclosure; assess risk; notify OCR if required; develop corrective action: implement better access controls; enhance privacy training; improve audit controls; implement technical safeguards; review business associate agreements; strengthen segregation of sensitive data; notify insurance
documentation_requirements: Document disclosure incident: description of what was disclosed; to whom it was disclosed; how disclosure occurred; risk assessment findings; individuals notified; notification letters; OCR notification; corrective actions; internal investigation; policy review; training updates; system changes; ongoing monitoring; third-party assessment; compliance certification
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (if pattern or failure to assess); State Attorneys General (Privacy Rule violations; state law violations); State health departments; Plaintiffs attorneys; Patients; Business Associates (if BA caused); Media (public disclosure)
penalty_tier: Tier 1-3 ($100-$100K per violation depending on culpability; up to $1.5M for category per year)
related_requirements: HITECH-13410-R1-R3 (Minimum necessary principle); HITECH-13411-R1-R2 (Individual restrictions); HITECH-13417 (Enhanced privacy/security); HITECH-13416-R1-R2 (Corrective action); Requirement for access controls; Requirement for audit logging; Requirement for privacy training
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Violation; Unauthorized Access; Privacy Rule Violation; Incident Response; Risk Assessment; Breach Notification; Regulatory Compliance; Minimum Necessary Principle; Access Control Failure
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13410 (Minimum necessary); Section 13411 (Restrictions); Section 13417 (Enhanced privacy); 45 CFR 164.502 (Privacy Rule); 45 CFR 164.514 (De-identification); 45 CFR 164.530 (Administrative requirements)
success_criteria: Unauthorized disclosure contained; Recipient identified; Risk assessment completed; OCR notification if required; Affected individual notification completed; Access controls enhanced; Audit logging improved; Privacy training conducted; Corrective action plan implemented; Ongoing monitoring in place; No pattern of unauthorized disclosures
failure_consequences: Failure results in: Tier 1-3 penalties; Privacy Rule violations finding; OCR enforcement and audit; Corrective action plan; Repeat violation penalties increase; Pattern violation leads to higher penalties; Patient lawsuits; State AG enforcement; Reputational damage; Loss of patient trust; Regulatory scrutiny; Enhanced monitoring; Possible suspension of certain operations

description: Attempted or successful access to ePHI by individual not authorized to access that specific information; includes excessive access beyond need-to-know; access by terminated employee; access after hours without authorization; access from unusual location; access by contractor outside scope
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA: unauthorized access to ePHI in violation of access control requirements; exceeding authorized access scope; accessing information without need-to-know; attempting to access information; accessing as different user; accessing using another's credentials; accessing outside normal job function
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Genetic Information; Biometric Data; Financial PHI; Substance Abuse Records; Mental Health Records; Any category accessed without authorization
typical_causes: Weak passwords; Shared accounts; Unencrypted portable devices; Unattended unlocked workstations; Shoulder surfing; Social engineering/phishing; Malware/spyware; Terminated employee with remaining access; Contractor access not revoked; Excessive access rights; Default credentials; Unpatched systems; Insufficient audit logging; Inadequate access controls; Insider threat; Competitor spying; Former employee revenge; Credential theft
detection_methods: Audit log showing unauthorized user access; Anomalous access patterns (bulk exports; access at unusual hours; access from unusual locations; rapid sequence of accesses); Failed authentication attempts; System administrator alert; Peer review during access audit; Manager notification; Employee complaint; Change in user behavior; Performance analytics anomaly; SIEM alert; Intrusion detection system alert
investigation_scope: Investigation: identify unauthorized user; determine what information accessed; determine if data exfiltrated; assess scope (single record or widespread); assess intent (accidental or malicious); review access logs; interview subject; review job responsibilities; assess authorization level; determine if intentional violation; assess pattern; determine if criminal activity involved; preserve evidence
notification_required: Yes - if information actually accessed and data sensitive; Risk assessment to determine notification need
notification_timeline: Determined by risk assessment (typically 60 days); Notification only if information accessed was sensitive and risk of misuse exists
notification_recipients: Affected individuals (if sensitive data accessed and risk exists); Manager/supervisor (if employee violation); HR (if employee violation); Law enforcement (if criminal); Internal audit; Compliance officer; Business associate (if BA employee)
risk_assessment_criteria: Risk assessment: (1) What information was accessed; (2) By whom; (3) For what purpose; (4) Whether data was exfiltrated; Aggravating factors: sensitive data categories accessed (substance abuse; genetic; mental health); large volume accessed; access outside normal job function; access during off-hours; access from suspicious location; multiple failed authentication attempts suggesting hacking; pattern of unauthorized access; malicious intent suspected
remediation_requirements: Immediate actions: disable access for unauthorized user; require password reset; review all access logs; analyze what was actually accessed; quarantine any exfiltrated data; notify law enforcement if criminal; notify affected individuals if data sensitive; establish monitoring; corrective actions: implement MFA; improve access controls; enhance audit logging; better separation of duties; access review procedures; training for manager/staff; system hardening; termination or discipline if employee misconduct
documentation_requirements: Document unauthorized access incident: description of access; person accessing; information accessed; unauthorized nature; access logs showing violation; risk assessment; actions taken; individuals notified; law enforcement notification; internal investigation; corrective actions; system changes; training; ongoing monitoring; employee discipline if applicable
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (if pattern; if failure to detect); Law enforcement (if criminal hacking); FBI (if criminal hacking); Plaintiffs attorneys (if breach); Employer (if employee); State Attorneys General (if criminal)
penalty_tier: Tier 2-3 ($1K-$100K per violation; up to $1.5M per category per year) if failure to detect or prevent; Criminal penalties for intentional unauthorized access
related_requirements: HITECH-13417-R3 (Access control enhancement); HITECH-13418-R1 (Safe Harbor); HITECH-13408-R3 (Audit logging); HITECH-13416-R1-R2 (Corrective action); Requirement for unique user IDs; Requirement for MFA; Requirement for RBAC; Requirement for audit logging
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Violation; Unauthorized Access; Access Control Failure; Incident Response; Risk Assessment; Accountability; Audit Logging; Insider Threat
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13408 (BA audit logging); Section 13417 (Enhanced access controls); Section 13418 (Safe Harbor); 45 CFR 164.312(a)(2)(i) (Unique IDs); 45 CFR 164.312(a)(2)(ii) (Access controls)
success_criteria: Unauthorized access immediately disabled; User identified; Access logs reviewed; Risk assessment completed; Individuals notified if required; Access controls enhanced; Audit logging improved; MFA implementation; Training conducted; No unauthorized access patterns detected; Corrective action plan implemented
failure_consequences: Failure results in: Tier 2-3 penalties; Access control finding; OCR enforcement; Corrective action plan; Ongoing monitoring; Repeat violations increase penalties; Criminal prosecution if hacking; Employee prosecution if misconduct; State AG enforcement; Patient lawsuits; Reputational damage; Loss of patient trust

description: Loss of PHI through theft of devices equipment or records; loss through disaster; loss through improper disposal; loss through supply chain compromise; loss of portable devices with unencrypted data
regulatory_definition: Under HITECH: loss of unsecured ePHI through theft of device; loss through physical document theft; loss through disaster; loss through natural causes; loss presumed compromised unless demonstrated otherwise through risk assessment
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Genetic Information; Biometric Data; Financial PHI; Substance Abuse Records; Mental Health Records; Any category on lost/stolen device or document
typical_causes: Theft of unencrypted laptop; Theft of USB drive with unencrypted data; Theft of mobile device with ePHI; Theft of paper records; Loss of portable device at airport/hotel; Supply chain compromise of hardware; Natural disaster destroying unencrypted backup; Improper disposal of hard drive; Dumpster diving; Vehicle theft with records; Courier package interception; Mail interception; Third-party loss of ePHI
detection_methods: Missing device reported; Missing document reported; Inventory audit showing discrepancy; Police report of theft; Vendor notification of lost shipment; Disaster damage to facility; Employee report of theft; Audit finding device unaccounted for; Audit finding encryption not in use; Vendor security incident notification; Supply chain compromise notification; Facility security report; Insurance claim; Backup recovery attempt fails
investigation_scope: Investigation: inventory all affected devices/documents; confirm loss vs. misplacement; determine scope of data lost; determine if device/document had encryption; determine if data exfiltrated; check if recovered; assess risk of misuse; contact law enforcement; review physical security; review disposal procedures; identify root cause; assess business continuity impact; insurance investigation
notification_required: Yes - MANDATORY if unsecured ePHI lost; Risk assessment if encrypted (may show no compromise)
notification_timeline: 60 days from discovery of loss/theft (if unsecured); May be shorter if high risk; Encrypted data may be exempted from notification if key not compromised
notification_recipients: Affected individuals; Media (if 500+ affected); HHS OCR; State Attorney General; Law enforcement; Device/document owner; Insurance company; Business associate (if BA device/document)
risk_assessment_criteria: Risk assessment: (1) What information lost; (2) How many records affected; (3) Whether data encrypted (if encrypted likely no compromise); (4) Whether lost device/document recovered; Encryption is major factor: Encrypted ePHI may be safe harbor (no notification required); Unencrypted triggers notification; Pattern of losses (major corrective action needed)
remediation_requirements: Immediately: report to law enforcement; secure remaining data; check for unauthorized use/fraud; notify insurance; activate business continuity; corrective actions: implement encryption for all portable devices; improve physical security; enhance inventory controls; improve disposal procedures; require sign-out/sign-in for portable devices; implement device tracking software; mandate encryption policies; enhance staff training; review vendor security; establish asset management procedures; audit third-party device handling
documentation_requirements: Document loss/theft incident: report to law enforcement; police report number; description of lost data; number of individuals affected; notification to OCR; notification to State AGs; notification to individuals; insurance claim; business continuity actions; corrective actions; device recovery status; risk assessment findings; encryption status; audit of similar devices; policy changes; staff retraining; third-party audit if vendor loss
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (primary); State Attorneys General; Law enforcement; FBI (if criminal theft); Insurance company; Plaintiffs attorneys; Device manufacturer (if vendor loss); Media
penalty_tier: Tier 4 ($20K-$50K minimum per violation; up to $1.5M per category per year) if unencrypted; Tier 3 if encrypted but key compromised; No Tier penalty if encrypted and key not compromised (Safe Harbor)
related_requirements: HITECH-13402-R1 (Breach notification if unsecured); HITECH-13406-R5 (Safe Harbor - encryption requirement); HITECH-13418-R1 (Safe Harbor); HITECH-13417-R2 (Encryption requirement); Requirement for physical safeguards; Requirement for portable device encryption; Requirement for device disposal
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Breach; Data Loss; Physical Security Failure; Breach Notification; Safe Harbor Evaluation; Risk Assessment; Incident Response; Encryption Standards
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions - unsecured ePHI); Section 13402 (Breach notification); Section 13406 (Safe Harbor); Section 13418 (Safe Harbor); 45 CFR 164.310 (Physical safeguards); 45 CFR 164.312 (Technical safeguards - encryption)
success_criteria: Lost/stolen device inventory complete; Risk assessment completed; Encrypted devices confirmed safe harbor; Unencrypted data notified as required; Law enforcement report filed; Insurance claim submitted; Business continuity restored; Encryption policy implemented for all portable devices; Device tracking implemented; Physical security enhanced; No similar losses; Corrective actions in place
failure_consequences: Failure results in: Tier 4 penalties if unencrypted; Breach notification required; Class action lawsuits; OCR enforcement and audit; Corrective action plan; Safe Harbor protection lost; Criminal prosecution if theft; Employee prosecution if negligence; State AG enforcement; Reputational damage; Business continuity disruption; Insurance denial; Loss of patient trust; Regulatory scrutiny; Media coverage; Long-term security costs

description: Infection of systems with malware ransomware virus worm trojan botware or other malicious code that compromises system security or enables unauthorized access to ePHI; includes ransomware attacks demanding payment; includes cryptolocker variants; includes system encryption attacks
regulatory_definition: Under HITECH and HIPAA: malware infection that enables unauthorized access to ePHI; ransomware attack that denies access to ePHI; malware that exfiltrates ePHI; system compromise from malicious code enabling breach
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Genetic Information; Biometric Data; Financial PHI; Substance Abuse Records; Mental Health Records; Any category on infected system; Data used by ransomware attackers
typical_causes: Phishing emails with malicious attachments; Compromised websites with drive-by downloads; Unpatched systems; Outdated software; Weak passwords; No endpoint protection; Lateral movement from compromised systems; Supply chain compromise; Watering hole attacks; USB insertion; Removable media; Contractor systems; Inadequate network segmentation; Insufficient monitoring
detection_methods: System performance degradation; System crashes; Unusual network traffic; File encryption (ransomware indicator); Pop-up messages; Inability to access files; Ransom demand; Antivirus alerts; SIEM alerts; Security tool detections; Backup failure (encrypted backups); Network monitoring alerts; User reports of unusual behavior; Incident response team notification; Threat intel notification
investigation_scope: Full forensic investigation: identify malware type; trace infection vector; determine scope of infection; identify compromised systems; assess lateral movement; determine what data accessed; assess data exfiltration; determine encryption status; recover from backup; assess ransom demand legitimacy; coordinate with law enforcement; preserve evidence; timeline malware activity; assess business continuity impact; determine if patient data exfiltrated
notification_required: Yes - if malware potentially accessed ePHI; Risk assessment to determine notification need
notification_timeline: Determined by investigation timeline (typically 60 days); May be accelerated if data exfiltrated; Notification if malware enabled unauthorized access to ePHI
notification_recipients: Affected individuals (if ePHI compromised); Media (if 500+ affected); HHS OCR; State Attorney General; Law enforcement; FBI (if sophisticated attack); Patients; Business associates (if BA system compromised); Insurance
risk_assessment_criteria: Risk assessment: (1) What system infected; (2) What ePHI accessible on system; (3) Whether ePHI exfiltrated; (4) Whether encryption maintained; Aggravating factors: ransomware demand (assumes access); lateral movement (wider impact); multiple systems infected (coordination needed); backups compromised (recovery issues); data exfiltration evidence (definite breach); financial data (high impact); genetic/substance abuse/mental health data (highest impact)
remediation_requirements: Immediate: isolate infected system; stop ransomware spread; preserve evidence; contact law enforcement; assess if data exfiltrated; determine backup status; prevent lateral movement; activate incident response; restore from clean backup if available; corrective actions: patch vulnerabilities; update antivirus/malware protection; deploy SIEM monitoring; improve endpoint protection; employee training on phishing; network segmentation; backup procedures; incident response plan; security assessment; third-party forensics if needed
documentation_requirements: Document malware incident: forensic report; system infection details; malware type identification; lateral movement assessment; data access assessment; data exfiltration determination; ransom demand details; law enforcement report; law enforcement coordination; backup status; recovery timeline; individuals notified; OCR notification; corrective actions; system hardening; training updates; ongoing monitoring; post-incident review
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR; State Attorneys General; Law enforcement; FBI (if sophisticated); Plaintiffs attorneys (if breach); Insurance company; System vendor; Malware analysis firms; Media (if public knowledge)
penalty_tier: Tier 4 ($20K-$50K+ per violation) if ePHI accessed/exfiltrated; Tier 3 if high risk; Criminal penalties if criminal hacking
related_requirements: HITECH-13402-R1 (Breach notification if ePHI accessed); HITECH-13417-R4 (Enhanced monitoring); HITECH-13406-R5 (Safe Harbor - if contained); HITECH-13418-R1; HITECH-13416-R1-R2 (Corrective action); Requirement for vulnerability management; Requirement for endpoint protection; Requirement for backup procedures
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Breach; Unauthorized Access; System Compromise; Incident Response; Forensic Investigation; Ransomware Attack; Business Continuity; Breach Notification; Malware Response; Law Enforcement Coordination
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13402 (Breach notification); Section 13417 (Enhanced security); Section 13416 (Corrective actions); Best practice incident response
success_criteria: Malware identified and isolated; Lateral movement contained; Forensic investigation completed; Data exfiltration assessment completed; Clean backup restored; Affected individuals notified if ePHI accessed; Law enforcement coordinated; Vulnerability patched; Endpoint protection enhanced; Monitoring implemented; No re-infection; Corrective action plan implemented; Post-incident training completed
failure_consequences: Failure results in: Tier 4 penalties if data exfiltrated; Extended business disruption; Ransom payment (not recoverable); Data loss if backups also compromised; Breach notification required; OCR investigation and audit; Corrective action plan; Class action lawsuits; Criminal prosecution if hacking; State AG enforcement; Reputational damage; Loss of patient trust; Operational disruption; Recovery costs; Forensic investigation costs; Regulatory scrutiny

description: Intentional or unintentional misuse of access by employee contractor temporary staff or other insider; includes accessing PHI without authorization; accessing outside job scope; selling PHI; sharing with unauthorized parties; revenge access; curiosity browsing; leaving PHI unsecured
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA and HITECH: insider unauthorized access to ePHI; insider disclosure of PHI; insider theft of PHI; insider using ePHI for unauthorized purpose; negligent handling enabling breach; inadequate controls enabling insider misconduct
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Genetic Information; Biometric Data; Financial PHI; Substance Abuse Records; Mental Health Records; Celebrity/VIP records; Any category accessible by insider with access
typical_causes: Disgruntled employee; Employee with financial difficulties; Contractor with poor security practices; Temporary staff inadequately supervised; Contractor access not properly restricted; Revenge motivation; Curiosity/snooping; Selling data to third parties; Family member accessing relative's records; Employee accessing own family member records for surveillance; Inadequate audit controls; Inadequate supervision; Weak enforcement of policies; Lack of consequences for violations
detection_methods: Audit log showing unusual access patterns; Unusual access by employee; Access outside job scope; Access of celebrity/VIP records; Access of family member records; Volume of access suspicious; Time patterns unusual; Employee behavior changes; Peer report; Patient complaint about unauthorized access; Comparison with job function; Failed to return credentials; Insider trading following PHI access; Third-party report of data sale; Employee bragging; Social media posts; Investigation following other incident
investigation_scope: Investigation: review access logs; assess authorization level; determine actual job function; assess need-to-know; interview employee; determine intent; assess what information accessed; assess if exfiltrated; assess if sold/shared; review communications; assess pattern; review training records; determine if policy enforcement deficient; assess manager's knowledge; preserve evidence for potential prosecution; coordinate with HR and legal
notification_required: Yes - if information actually accessed was sensitive and employee misused it
notification_timeline: Determined by investigation; Typically 60 days; May extend if criminal investigation underway
notification_recipients: Affected individuals (if sensitive data accessed and misused); HR (for employment action); Law enforcement (if criminal); Internal audit; Compliance officer; Patients whose records accessed; OCR (if pattern)
risk_assessment_criteria: Risk assessment: (1) What information accessed; (2) What was done with it; (3) Whether sold/shared/misused; (4) Scope of affected individuals; Aggravating factors: selling PHI (criminal); disclosing to media (high breach impact); accessing family members (multiple ethics violations); celebrity/VIP records (high reputation risk); financial data with account numbers (fraud risk); substance abuse records (federal crime under 42 CFR Part 2); genetic information (discrimination risk); pattern of unauthorized access (systematic misconduct)
remediation_requirements: Immediate: disable employee access; conduct investigation; preserve evidence; interview employee; review all access; determine if criminal activity; contact law enforcement if criminal; notify affected individuals; corrective actions: implement better supervision; improve audit controls; enforce access review procedures; implement monitoring; disciplinary action up to termination; training enhancement; access control improvements; monitoring for similar behavior; policy enforcement; third-party investigation if needed
documentation_requirements: Document insider threat incident: access logs; investigation report; authorization review; employment file; training documentation; policy acknowledgment; interview notes; determination of intent; corrective actions; disciplinary record; individual notifications; OCR notification if pattern; law enforcement report if criminal; ongoing monitoring; background check if rehiring; exit procedures if termination
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (if pattern or serious); Law enforcement (if criminal sale of data); FBI (if enterprise espionage); Plaintiffs attorneys (if breach); Employer (HR and legal); State Attorneys General; Media (if high profile)
penalty_tier: Tier 2-4 ($1K-$100K+ per violation) depending on intent and scope; Criminal penalties if selling data or criminal activity; Tier 4 if pattern or systematic misconduct
related_requirements: HITECH-13408-R3 (Audit logging to detect); HITECH-13417-R3 (Access control to prevent); HITECH-13418-R1 (Safe Harbor audit controls); HITECH-13416-R1-R2 (Corrective action); Requirement for access review; Requirement for audit logging; Requirement for training; Requirement for enforcement
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Violation; Insider Threat; Unauthorized Access; Audit Logging Effectiveness; Training Effectiveness; Incident Response; Accountability; Criminal Misconduct
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13408 (BA audit controls); Section 13417 (Access control enhancements); Section 13416 (Corrective actions); Criminal codes (unauthorized computer access; data theft; fraud)
success_criteria: Unauthorized access immediately disabled; Investigation completed; Intent determined; Affected individuals notified; Law enforcement coordinated; Disciplinary action taken; Access controls improved; Audit monitoring enhanced; Training reinforced; No pattern of similar incidents; Corrective action plan implemented
failure_consequences: Failure results in: Tier 2-4 penalties; Pattern of insider incidents findings; OCR enforcement and audit; Corrective action plan; Criminal prosecution of employee; Employee lawsuits for wrongful termination; State AG enforcement; Breach notification; Class action lawsuits; Reputational damage; Loss of patient trust; Operational disruption; Loss of employee productivity; Media coverage; Regulatory scrutiny

description: Breach of ePHI occurring at or by a Business Associate; includes breach by contractor; includes breach by vendor; includes breach by subcontractor; includes breach by hosted service provider; includes supply chain compromise; includes loss at third party vendor
regulatory_definition: Under HITECH Section 13404: Business Associate must notify covered entity without unreasonable delay and in no case later than 60 days of discovery of breach; covered entity responsible for notifying individuals even if breach by BA
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Genetic Information; Biometric Data; Financial PHI; Substance Abuse Records; Mental Health Records; Any category handled by Business Associate; Any category in hosted/cloud service; Backup data at third party
typical_causes: Inadequate BA safeguards; Inadequate BA audit controls; Inadequate BA hiring practices; Inadequate BAA language; Failure to flow down requirements to subcontractors; Vendor security incident; Supply chain compromise; Inadequate vendor selection; Inadequate vendor monitoring; Inadequate contract terms; Inadequate incident response coordination; Vendor bankruptcy; Vendor sale of company; Vendor change in ownership affecting security
detection_methods: Business Associate notification of breach; BA security incident report; Vendor notification; Breach disclosure press release; Audit finding BA incident; Insurance investigation; Regulatory notification; Law enforcement report; Media report; Customer/patient complaint; Supply chain compromise notification; Vendor assessment findings; Audit of BA systems
investigation_scope: Investigation: coordinate with BA for forensic investigation; determine scope of BA breach; determine what CE data affected; assess BA's investigative findings; assess BA's notification compliance; assess BA's remediation; assess underlying cause; assess whether subcontractor involved; assess root cause in BA selection/monitoring; assess BAA adequacy; assess future risk; determine if law enforcement involved; assess vendor viability
notification_required: Yes - covered entity must notify individuals even if breach by BA; BA must notify CE; CE must notify individuals
notification_timeline: 60 days from CE discovery of BA breach; BA must notify CE within 60 days; CE responsible for ultimate individual notification timeline
notification_recipients: Individuals affected by BA breach; Media (if 500+); HHS OCR; State Attorneys General; Law enforcement; BA patients (if BA directly treats); Business Associate; Insurance; Business associate's customers
risk_assessment_criteria: Risk assessment same as covered entity breach: (1) What CE data was in BA's possession; (2) What CE data was affected; (3) Whether CE data was accessed; (4) Whether CE data was exfiltrated; Factors: Scope of BA's access (limited or broad); BA's obligations (BAA terms); BA's investments in security; BA's prior incidents; Availability of BA forensic investigation; BA's cooperation with investigation; BA's remediation efforts; Impact on covered entity and patients
remediation_requirements: Immediate: obtain BA forensic findings; assess CE's liability; notify legal/insurance; prepare individual notification; prepare media response if needed; determine OCR notification obligations; corrective actions: review BAA adequacy; assess BA's remediation; consider changing BA; implement enhanced monitoring of BAs; audit other BAs; review subcontractor flow-down; enhance BA selection criteria; implement BA oversight procedures; consider backup vendors; legal action against BA if negligent
documentation_requirements: Document BA breach: BA forensic report; BA notification letter; BA remediation plan; BAA review; assessment of BA liability; CE's individual notification; CE's media notification; CE's OCR notification; legal review; insurance claim; BA communications; audit of other BAs; BAA amendment; vendor assessment; ongoing monitoring; post-incident review
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (primary - both CE and BA); State Attorneys General; Law enforcement; Plaintiffs attorneys; Covered entity's insurance; Business associate's insurance; Media; CE's business partners; BA's customers
penalty_tier: Tier 4 ($20K-$50K+ per violation) for covered entity; Tier 4 for BA ($20K-$50K+ per violation for BA's breach); Additional penalties if BA failure to notify; Additional penalties if inadequate BAA
related_requirements: HITECH-13402-R1-R5 (CE breach notification); HITECH-13404-R1-R2 (BA notification to CE; CE notification to individuals); HITECH-13405-R1-R5 (BAA requirements); HITECH-13406-R1-R4 (Penalties apply to BA); HITECH-13408-R1-R4 (BA safeguards); HITECH-13423 (Subcontractors); Requirement for BAA; Requirement for BA monitoring
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Breach; Business Associate Accountability; Breach Notification; Vendor Risk Management; Contract Management; Incident Response; Third-Party Breach; Supply Chain Security
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13404 (BA breach notification); Section 13405 (BA agreements); Section 13408 (BA safeguards); Section 13423 (Subcontractors); 45 CFR 164.504 (BA requirements)
success_criteria: BA notifies CE without unreasonable delay; CE investigation completed; Forensic findings reviewed; Individual notification completed within 60 days; Media notification completed; OCR notification completed; BA remediation plan approved; BAA reviewed and amended; Enhanced BA monitoring implemented; Other BAs audited; No ongoing risk; Corrective action plan implemented
failure_consequences: Failure results in: Tier 4 penalties for CE; Tier 4 penalties for BA; BA notification delay penalties; CE notification delay penalties; OCR enforcement of both CE and BA; Corrective action plans for both; Class action lawsuits against CE and BA; State AG enforcement; Loss of patient trust; Reputational damage for CE (responsible even if BA fault); Business relationship termination; Insurance denial if BA at fault; BA potential business closure; Industry scrutiny; Regulatory monitoring; Media coverage

description: Ransomware attack that encrypts systems and/or data and demands ransom payment for decryption key; includes cryptolocker; includes wiper malware; includes denial of service through encryption; threatens disclosure of ePHI if ransom not paid
regulatory_definition: Under HITECH: ransomware presumed to cause compromise of ePHI (breach) unless demonstrated otherwise; extortion threat indicates ePHI may be exfiltrated; attack may prevent access to ePHI causing business continuity impact
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Any category on affected systems (all data on encrypted system); Genetic Information; Biometric Data; Financial PHI; Substance Abuse Records; Mental Health Records; Backups (if encrypted); Business continuity systems
typical_causes: Phishing with malicious attachment; Vulnerable RDP access; Unpatched systems; Supply chain compromise; Watering hole attack; Previous malware infection enabling lateral movement; Inadequate network segmentation; No backup protection; Inadequate endpoint protection; Weak passwords; No MFA; Insufficient monitoring; Contractor system compromise; Third-party access compromise
detection_methods: Ransom demand note; System encryption; Inability to access files; System performance degradation; Backup encryption; Network monitoring alerts; Ransom negotiation contact; Threat disclosure if ransom not paid; Data posted to dark web; Media notification threat; Patient notification threat; Law enforcement report; Incident response alert; Forensic findings
investigation_scope: Full forensic investigation required: identify ransomware variant; trace infection vector; determine scope of systems affected; assess network spread; determine if data exfiltrated before encryption; examine extortion threats; assess ransom demand legitimacy; coordinate with law enforcement and FBI; assess business continuity impact; restore from clean backups; assess encryption strength; preserve evidence; assess ransom payment options; determine if threat is legitimate
notification_required: Yes - MANDATORY if data exfiltrated; Presumed breach unless thorough investigation shows no data access; Extortion demand indicates data accessed
notification_timeline: 60 days from discovery; May be accelerated if data exfiltration evidence found; Notification if presumed breach
notification_recipients: Affected individuals (if data exfiltrated or breach presumed); Media (if 500+ affected or extortion threat); Law enforcement; FBI; HHS OCR; State Attorney General; Patients; Insurance; Business partners
risk_assessment_criteria: Risk assessment: (1) What system encrypted; (2) Whether backups encrypted; (3) Whether data exfiltrated (extortion threat indicates yes); (4) Ransom threat to disclose data; Presumption: Ransom attack = data access unless proven otherwise; Extortion threat = data exfiltration likely; Extortion threat = extortion attempt likely, demands potential criminal prosecution
remediation_requirements: Immediate: do NOT pay ransom (funds criminal enterprise); contact law enforcement; contact FBI; contact HHS OCR; preserve extortion communications; assess backup status; restore from clean backup if available; isolate systems; prevent lateral movement; corrective actions: patch vulnerability; implement MFA; segmentation; endpoint protection; backup protection; SIEM monitoring; incident response plan; employee training; third-party forensics; business continuity plan; assess ransom demand source; law enforcement pursuit of attackers; criminal prosecution of attackers if identified
documentation_requirements: Document ransomware incident: forensic report; ransom demand and communications; system infection details; lateral movement assessment; data exfiltration determination; backup status; recovery timeline; law enforcement report and coordination; OCR notification; individual notification; media notification; corrective actions; system hardening; training updates; ongoing monitoring; post-incident review; ransom demand source investigation
enforcement_authority: HHS OCR (primary); Law enforcement (FBI; local police); State Attorneys General; Plaintiffs attorneys; Insurance company; Cybersecurity firms; Media; Business partners; Patients; Ransomware tracking organizations
penalty_tier: Tier 4 ($20K-$50K+ per violation); Criminal penalties for ransomware attackers (federal crime); Additional penalties if ransom paid funds criminal enterprise; State AG enforcement; Civil RICO if criminal enterprise
related_requirements: HITECH-13402-R1 (Breach notification if data accessed); HITECH-13417-R4 (Enhanced monitoring); HITECH-13406-R5 (Safe Harbor if no access); HITECH-13418-R1; HITECH-13416-R1-R2 (Corrective action); Requirement for backup procedures; Requirement for incident response; Requirement for law enforcement coordination; Requirement for ransom demand reporting to law enforcement
domains_covered: Privacy & Security Breach; System Compromise; Ransom Attack; Extortion; Unauthorized Access; Business Continuity; Incident Response; Law Enforcement Coordination; Forensic Investigation; Breach Notification; Criminal Investigation
applicable_sections: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13402 (Breach notification); Section 13417 (Enhanced security); Section 13416 (Corrective actions); 18 USC 1030 (Computer fraud); Criminal extortion statutes
success_criteria: Ransomware contained and systems restored; Forensic investigation completed; Data exfiltration assessment completed; Ransom demand NOT paid; Law enforcement engaged; FBI engaged; Clean backup restored; Affected individuals notified if data exfiltrated; Law enforcement coordinated; Vulnerability patched; Endpoint protection enhanced; Monitoring implemented; Backup protection enhanced; No re-infection; Corrective action plan implemented; Post-incident training completed
failure_consequences: Failure results in: Tier 4 penalties; Ransom payment (funds criminal enterprise; unrecoverable); Data loss if backups also compromised; Operational shutdown; Business continuity disruption; Breach notification required; OCR investigation; Corrective action plan; Class action lawsuits; Criminal prosecution of attackers (if identified); State AG enforcement; Reputational damage; Loss of patient trust; Recovery costs; Forensic investigation costs; Regulatory scrutiny; Media coverage; Criminal liability if ransom paid to foreign adversaries

event_type_name: Unauthorized Modification or Deletion of ePHI
description: Unauthorized modification deletion or alteration of ePHI without authorization; includes data tampering; includes deletion of medical records; includes falsification of records; includes modification to cover up unauthorized access; includes ransomware wiper attacks
regulatory_definition: Under HITECH and HIPAA: unauthorized alteration of PHI compromising accuracy and integrity of medical records; deletion of PHI; destruction of records impacting patient care; falsification of records; destruction of evidence of unauthorized access; wiper malware destroying data
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Medical records integrity; Audit logs (if deleted); Backup integrity; Clinical data; Medication records; Diagnosis records; Test results; Treatment records; Any category altered without authorization
typical_causes: Insider modification; Malware wiper attack; Inadvertent system error; Inadequate access controls; Inadequate change management; Inadequate audit controls; Unauthorized delete command; Database modification; File deletion; Ransomware wiper destroying files; System administrator error; Contractor modification; Contractor deletion; Log manipulation; Backup deletion
detection_methods: Audit detecting data modification; Audit detecting data deletion; System integrity check failure; Backup integrity check failure; Change log showing unauthorized change; User complaint about missing/altered records; System administrator detecting deletion; Version control showing modification; Data validation error; Medical records showing discrepancies; Audit log deletion detected; Hash mismatch on data integrity check; SIEM alert on data modification
investigation_scope: Investigation: identify what was modified/deleted; identify who modified/deleted; assess authorization; assess intent; recover deleted data from backup; assess timeline of modification; assess scope; determine if to cover up unauthorized access; determine if malware related; assess business continuity impact; assess patient care impact; review change management; review audit controls; preserve evidence; assess pattern of modifications; determine if criminal falsification of records
notification_required: Yes - if modification impacts patient care or deletes required records; Risk assessment to determine if breach (depends on nature of modification); May not need individual notification if internal audit trail preserved
notification_timeline: Determined by investigation; May not require external notification if internal controls detected and remediated; If patient care impacted
notification_recipients: must notify patients; If medical records destroyed
remediation_requirements: Affected patients (if care-related or records destroyed); Medical staff (if records impact patient care); OCR (if deliberate destruction); State medical board (if patient care impact); Law enforcement (if criminal tampering); Compliance officer; IT security
documentation_requirements: Risk assessment: (1) What data modified/deleted; (2) By whom; (3) Whether authorized; (4) Whether to cover up other breach; (5) Patient care impact; Aggravating factors: modification of medical records affecting diagnosis/treatment (patient safety); deletion of medication records (patient safety); deletion of allergy information (patient safety); deletion of audit logs (cover-up); pattern of modifications (systematic misconduct); criminal falsification of records (felony)
enforcement_authority: Immediate: restore from backup; verify data integrity; preserve evidence; assess patient care impact; notify medical staff if patient care affected; investigate cause; correct data; law enforcement notification if criminal; corrective actions: implement change management; enhance audit controls; implement data integrity verification; implement access controls; implement immutable audit logs; monitoring implementation; staff training; system hardening; testing backup recovery procedures; policy enforcement
penalty_tier: Document unauthorized modification: backup restoration proof; data recovery; change logs; access logs; investigation findings; determination of cause; patient care impact assessment; medical staff notifications; OCR notification if required; law enforcement report if criminal; corrective actions; system changes; audit controls enhancement; training; ongoing monitoring; post-incident review; backup test results
related_requirements: HHS OCR (if patient care impact or failure to detect); Law enforcement (if criminal record tampering); State medical board (if patient care impact); FBI (if computer fraud); Plaintiffs attorneys; State Attorneys General; Media; Patients
domains_covered: Tier 2-3 ($1K-$100K+ per violation); Criminal penalties if falsification of medical records (federal crime); Criminal penalties if obstruction of justice (destruction of evidence); Medical board penalties if patient care affected
applicable_sections: HITECH-13417-R4 (Enhanced monitoring); HITECH-13408-R3 (Audit logging); HITECH-13418-R1 (Safe Harbor audit controls); HITECH-13416-R1-R2 (Corrective action); Requirement for data integrity; Requirement for change management; Requirement for audit logging; Requirement for backup procedures
success_criteria: Privacy & Security Violation; Data Integrity; Unauthorized Access; Audit Logging Effectiveness; Patient Safety; Incident Response; Data Recovery; Accountability
failure_consequences: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13408 (BA audit controls); Section 13417 (Enhanced security); Section 13416 (Corrective actions); Medical record documentation requirements; 18 USC 1519 (Obstruction of justice - document destruction)
priority_level: Data restored from backup; Data integrity verified; Cause determined and corrected; Patient care impact assessed; Medical staff notified if needed; Access controls enhanced; Audit controls enhanced; Change management implemented; Monitoring in place; No ongoing integrity issues; Corrective action plan implemented; Backup testing confirmed
status: Failure results in: Tier 2-3 penalties; Patient safety incidents; Medical malpractice suits; State medical board investigation; OCR enforcement; Corrective action plan; Criminal prosecution if falsification of records; Criminal prosecution if obstruction of justice; Loss of medical license if individual practitioner; State AG enforcement; Reputational damage; Loss of patient trust; Operational disruption; Regulatory scrutiny; Media coverage

description: Identification of security vulnerability in systems with ePHI; unpatched system with known vulnerability exploitable for unauthorized access; zero-day vulnerability; vulnerable third-party component; inadequate configuration; default credentials; weak encryption; lack of access controls; vulnerability allowing lateral movement; vulnerability enabling data exfiltration
regulatory_definition: Under HIPAA: vulnerability that can enable unauthorized access to ePHI; unpatched system that failure to patch results in breach; vulnerability in covered entity or BA system; failure to remediate known vulnerability within reasonable timeframe
data_categories_affected: EPHI; Genetic Information; Biometric Data; Financial PHI; Substance Abuse Records; Mental Health Records; Any category on vulnerable system; Backup data if vulnerable system has access
typical_causes: Unpatched operating system; Unpatched application; Vulnerable third-party component; Outdated software; Inadequate configuration; Weak default credentials not changed; Missing firewall; Missing endpoint protection; Inadequate network segmentation; Weak password policy; Lack of MFA; Vulnerable API; Vulnerable web application; Vulnerable database; Vulnerable server; Inadequate encryption; Missing access controls; Inadequate audit logging; Lazy security practices
detection_methods: Vulnerability scanner finding; Penetration testing discovery; Security audit finding; CVE notification; Third-party security alert; Incident response discovering vulnerability; External researcher report; Bug bounty program report; Security testing finding; Configuration review finding; System assessment; Log analysis showing vulnerability exploitation attempt
investigation_scope: Investigation: assess vulnerability severity; determine if exploitable; determine what data at risk; determine if already exploited; review vulnerability notification; assess patch availability; assess patch timeline; assess workarounds; determine business impact of patching; assess if vendor patch delayed; assess if zero-day; contact vendor for timeline; coordinate patch deployment; test patch; assess other systems for same vulnerability; determine root cause (why unpatched)
notification_required: No direct notification required for vulnerability; Notification required only if vulnerability was exploited and breach occurred; Notification required if delay in patching causes breach
notification_timeline: Not applicable unless breach occurs; If exploitation suspected
risk_assessment_criteria: System owner/administrator (for patching); Security team (for oversight); CISO (for escalation); Business unit (for scheduling); Vendor (for patch request); Business associates (if shared system); Law enforcement (if exploitation suspected)
remediation_requirements: Risk assessment: (1) Vulnerability severity rating (CVSS score); (2) Exploitability (is public exploit available); (3) Impact if exploited (what data at risk); (4) Whether already exploited; Patch availability: Vendor patch available (lower urgency); No patch available - use workaround (higher urgency); Zero-day vulnerability (critical urgency)
documentation_requirements: Immediate: assess severity; determine if already exploited; create workaround if patch delayed; plan patch deployment; communicate timeline; deploy patch urgently if critical; correct configuration if configuration issue; change default credentials if applicable; implement compensating controls if patch unavailable; corrective actions: establish patch management process; schedule regular vulnerability scans; implement patch policy; test patches; automate patching where possible; vendor communication; asset inventory; configuration management; ongoing scanning
enforcement_authority: Document vulnerability: vulnerability report; severity assessment; exploitability assessment; patch status; patch deployment timeline; patch test results; patch deployment completion; any exploitation incidents; corrective actions; patch management policy; vulnerability scanning results; post-patch testing; ongoing monitoring; vendors contacted; patch timeline negotiated if delayed; workaround details
penalty_tier: HHS OCR (if inadequate patch management; if breach results); IT security; Risk management; Vendor security team; Third-party security researchers; Bug bounty program; Media (if major vulnerability publicly disclosed)
related_requirements: Tier 1-2 ($100-$100K+ per violation) for failure to patch; Tier 3-4 ($10K-$100K+ per violation) if unpatched system leads to breach; Criminal penalties if intentional neglect
domains_covered: HITECH-13417-R1 (Risk assessment includes vulnerability ID); HITECH-13418-R1 (Safe Harbor requires patching); HITECH-13408-R2 (BA requirement for patch management); HITECH-13416-R1-R2 (Corrective action); Requirement for vulnerability management; Requirement for patching; Requirement for testing
applicable_sections: Privacy & Security Vulnerability; Patch Management; System Hardening; Incident Response; Vulnerability Assessment; Technical Safeguards
success_criteria: Section 13400 (Definitions); Section 13417 (Enhanced security); Section 13418 (Safe Harbor - patching requirement); Section 13408 (BA requirements); Best practice vulnerability management
failure_consequences: Vulnerability identified; Severity assessed; Patch deployed or workaround implemented; Patch tested; Deployment completed; Vulnerability rescanned and verified resolved; Other systems checked for same vulnerability; Patch management process documented; Patch schedule maintained; Annual vulnerability scanning performed; No critical unpatched vulnerabilities; Corrective action plan implemented
priority_level: Failure results in: Tier 1-2 penalties; Tier 3-4 if breach results; Delayed patching enables breach; Vulnerability exploitation; Data compromise; OCR enforcement; Corrective action plan; Breach notification if exploited; Class action lawsuits; Regulatory scrutiny; Reputational damage; Loss of patient trust; Ongoing vulnerability; Repeat vulnerabilities; Vendor relationships damaged
